tossups.answer: Kate Chopin Bonuses:

parts: Name this conservation area about 100 miles west of Arusha, named for a gigantic crater that is an old caldera. This place also contains Olduvai Gorge and has Maswa and Serengeti National Park on its western border.
East of Arusha is this dormant volcano, the highest point in Africa.

The beaches on Zanzibar are another popular tourist destination in Tanzania, and they can be reached by ferries from this city. This city has been replaced as the capital by Dodoma, but it is still the largest city in Tanzania.
Name this play, in which the white Lula attempts to seduce the black Clay on a train. After he resists her, she murders him and chillingly contemplates her next victim.

Dutchman is by this second poet laureate of New Jersey. He described his daughter praying in “Preface to a Twenty Volume Suicide Note,” and wrote the controversial “Somebody Blew Up America?” after 9/11.

This other New Jersey poet wrote about a personified spirit “Eternally asleep, his dreams walk about the city” in his multi-volume epic Paterson. He also wrote about a midnight fridge-raid for plums in “This Is Just to Say.”

answers: Industrial Workers of the World [or IWW]
parts: Name this town where Little’s 1917 lynching set off years of labor strife, culminating in a 1920 massacre of picketing copper miners on this town’s Anaconda Road.
Frank Little was affiliated with this labor union, whose other members included “Mother” Jones and “Big Bill” Haywood. Members of this socialist-leaning union were referred to as “wobblies.”

Three months after Little’s death, 17 Wobblies were tarred and feathered by the KKK in this city’s namesake “outrage.” A white mob destroyed this city’s Greenwood District, known as “Black Wall Street,” in a 1921 race riot.

answers: social mobility [or economic mobility; or upward mobility]
parts: Name this type of differentiation in a society that produces an unequal hierarchy of socioeconomic roles.

One criticism of the Davis-Moore Thesis lies in the institutionalized barriers to achieving this goal of moving up the strata. When a person moves up the economic ladder, he is said to achieve the “upward” type of this goal.

This Princeton theorist published a response to the Davis-Moore Thesis in an article that argued stratification entrenched the current elite. He was also at the center of the controversy that inspired Roth’s The Human Stain.

answers: University of Sankore [or Sankore Masjid; Sankore Madrasah; prompt on “University of Timbuktu”]
parts: Name this institution built around a Mosque designed by Abu Ishaq as-Sahili. Ahmad Baba al Massufi was the most famous member of this institution, which was founded by judge Al-Qadi Aqib ibn Mahmud ibn Umar.
Sankore University was founded by this ruler of the Malian Empire, whose hajj legendarily depreciated the price of gold.
Sankore University was in Timbuktu, which would later be controlled by the Songhai Empire, which had its capital in this other city.
Name this performance artist. In her most famous piece, “The Artist is Present,” she allowed people to sit across from her for however long they wanted to create an emotional connection.

In the performance art piece I Like America and America Likes Me, the Fluxus artist Joseph Beuys (boyz) flew to the US, lived in a small room with this wild animal for 8 hours a day for 3 days, and flew back to Germany.
In a eulogy for this artist, Allan Kaprow argued that his emphasis on the act of painting by the “dance of dripping” foreshadowed performance art.
Name this literary movement co-founded by Leon Damas, which included works like “Midnight Elegy.” Another of its founders produced Notebook of a Return to the Native Land.

Aime Cesaire and this President of Senegal co-founded the Negritude movement. This man proclaimed “They call us men of death / We are the men of the dance” in “Prayer to the Masks,” part of his “Shadow Songs” collection.
Senghor’s poem to this city urges it to “listen to the distant beating of your nocturnal heart” and “let black blood flow into your blood.” In the ode, he is excited to have finally seen Harlem.

answers: difference is a half integer of the wavelength or anything equivalent
parts: Evidence for the wave nature of light was given by this experiment performed by Young, in which light produced an interference pattern after being shined on a plate with two holes.
In this variant of the double-slit experiment, the slit through which a photon passes is marked, and the interference pattern vanishes. This demonstrates entanglement.

The interference pattern in a double slit experiment will have dark fringes where destructive interference occurs. At those fringes, the path lengths for the two slits have this mathematical relationship.

Name this ruler of the heavens, who gave Obatala permission to climb down from heaven on a golden chain and pour sand on the water to create land; he also sent a chameleon to defeat Olokun in a weaving contest.
In Yoruba religion, Olorun is one of these deities. They include the trickster Eshu and the water deity Olokun.
The Yoruba people come from Benin and this modern-day country, which is also home to the Hausa and Igbo.

answers: metaphase II [prompt on “meiosis II”, prompt on “metaphase”, do NOT accept or prompt on “metaphase I”]
parts: Name this process that results in the formation of haploid gametes. Crossing over can occur during prophase I of this process.
To be more specific, crossing over occurs during this third subphase of Prophase I, when the chiasma can form in the synaptonemal complex. It immediately follows the zygotene stage.
In humans, meiosis is arrested at prophase I until puberty; during ovulation, eggs make it all the way to this phase before fertilization moves them past it.

answers: Henry III [or Henry of Winchester; prompt on partial answer]
parts: This monarch’s father was likely the first monarch to keep lions in the Tower of London. He was himself the recipient of 3 leopards from Frederick II and was given a polar bear by Norwegian monarch Haakon IV.

The ghost of this person supposedly still haunts the Tower of London, where she was executed for adultery. This maid to Catherine of Aragon was killed by her husband, Henry VIII, for failing to produce a male heir.

The disappearance of the “Princes in the Tower” allowed this person to claim the throne as the pretend Richard of Shrewsbury, with Margaret of York verifying his claim. This person led a revolt in Cornwall in 1497.
Many feminist epistemologists discuss this type of knower. This term refers to knowers in relation to what is known by other knowers.
Feminist empiricism experiences a paradox concerning this concept, due to its implication that androcentricity in the sciences should be made more objective via adopting feminist values.
Feminist philosopher Jose Medina discussed gendered and racial credibility in the context of this novel, in which Mayella Ewell’s testimony is regarded as more credible than Tom Robinson’s.
Name this piece of lab equipment, a transparent concave object used to evaporate liquids and hold powder.
A watch glass is commonly used during this process, in which a pure, highly organized solid falls out of solution. Adding hot solvent is a way to remove impurities via this technique.
One method of crystallization involves adding impurities to a solution that has undergone this process, in which its temperature is lowered below its freezing point, but it doesn’t freeze.

answers: knife [or knives; or daggers; or swords; basically accept any answer along these lines; prompt on general descriptions like “weapons”]
bracelets [or armlets; or bangle; prompt on “jewelry” even though that’s not really its purpose]
parts: Name these types of ceremonial objects that include the Sikh kirpan, which is one of the five articles of faith. Another more immediately practical example of these objects is the Gurkha khukri.

The kara is an iron or steel object of this kind that is worn at all times to identify oneself as Sikh and to serve as an ever-present reminder to abstain from wrongdoing. It also visually represents the infinite nature of God.
The five kakars, or five K’s, of Sikhism were mandated by this tenth Sikh guru as part of the consolidation of the Sikh community into the panth khalsa.

answers: The Unbearable Lightness of Being [or Nesnesitelná lehkost bytí]
parts: In this Pulitzer-winning Nilo Cruz play, the lector Juan Julian is hired to read Tolstoy to Cuban cigar rollers in Santiago’s factory and ends up falling in love with Conchita.
Although their dog is female, Tomas and Tereza name her Karenin. They take her to the countryside to escape Czech Communism in this Milan Kundera novel.

In Muriel Barbery’s The Elegance of the Hedgehog, Renee befriends Mr. Ozu due to his Anna Karenina - named cats: one is named Kitty and the other is named for this landowner, Kitty’s suitor and eventual husband.

answers: Scordatura [accept anything that implies changing the tuning]
parts: Name this classical genre that succeeded the concerto grosso, featuring soloists that are more integrated in the orchestra than a concerto. Mozart composed the most famous example of this piece in E-flat major for Violin and Viola.

In Sinfonia Concertante, Mozart calls the viola to practice this technique in order to make it sound louder; the violins are asked to do this in the final movement of Haydn’s Symphony No. 60, Il Distratto. Description acceptable.
This Russian composer dedicated his difficult Sinfonia Concertante to Mstislav Rostropovich. He is probably best known for composing Peter and the Wolf.

answers: Ivan the Terrible [or Ivan IV Vasilyevich; Ivan Grozny; prompt on partial answer]
Dmitri Donskoi [or Dmitri of the Don; Dmitri II; prompt on “Dmitri Ivanovich”; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this state whose massacre of merchants at its fair prompted the creation of the Makariev Fair. Saint Basil’s Cathedral was built to celebrate the conquest of this state.
The Khanate of Kazan fought against the princes of Moscow and was finally conquered by this Czar, who killed his son by hitting him with his staff and had his secret police sack Novgorod.
An earlier Muscovite who fought against the Mongols was this person, who defeated Mamai at the Battle of Kulikovo.
Name this English comic poet who wrote the collection Making Cocoa for Kingsley Amis and parodied a variety of writers via her fictional poet Jason Strugnell.
Cope spoofed this poet’s Arcadia with the line “My true love hath my heart and I have hers / We swapped last Tuesday.”
Cope condensed this landmark T. S. Eliot poem into a series of five limericks which starts with “In April one seldom feels cheerful” and ends with “Shantih. I hope you’ll make sense of the notes.”
Name this property equivalent to every cover having an open sub-cover, where the open sets are those from the topology induced on the dual by the double-dual.

Functional analysis is concerned with vector spaces with an infinite value for this quantity. Two vector spaces with the same finite value for this quantity are isomorphic, and it is equal to the number of elements in the basis.

In a finite dimensional vector space, every linear functional corresponds to taking this kind of product between two vectors. This product returns a scalar, and it can be used to compute the angle between two vectors.
These Archaic age statues were idealized versions of male nudes, standing with one foot placed forward and often smiling. Their female counterparts were often clothed but similarly idealized.
After the kouros’ upright posture, Greek artists introduced sculptures standing in this pose, placing most of their weight on one foot and twisting their torso.
A statue of this Greek goddess undraped to the waist was unearthed on Milos. Her arms are famously missing.
